purpose of navigation but their vessels were so
frequently plundered by their Dutch neighbours that
when they regained the good port of LoandaLuanda they no longer
made use of the river. We remained here
four days in hopes of obtaining an observation for
the longitude but at this season of the year the sky
is almost constantly overcast by a thick canopy
of clouds of a milk and water hue this continues
until the rainy season ^ which was now close at hand commences.

The lands on the north side of the Coanza belong to
the Quisamas (Kisamas) an independent tribe
which the Portuguese have not been able to subdue
The few who came under my observation possessed
? a little of the Bushman ofor HotentotHottentot feature and
were dressed in strips of bark hanging from the waist
to the knee. They deal largely in salt which their
country produces in great abundance. It is brought
in crystals of about 12 inches long and about 1½1/2 inch
in diameter This is met withhawked about everywhere in
Angola and next to calico is the most common
medium of barter The Kisama are brave and
when the Portuguese army pur followed them into
their forests they soon reduced the invaders to
extremity by tapping all the reservoirs of water
which were no other than the enormous Baobabs
of the country hollowed into cisterns . As the Kisama Country
is ill supplied with water otherwise, the Portuguese
were soon obliged to retreat. Their Country
near to Massangano is low lying and marshy
but becomes more elevated in the distance
and beyond them lie the ^ d lofty dark ^ mountain ranges of
mountains of the Libollo another powerful
& independent people Near Massangano
I observed what seemed to be an effort of nature
82
to furnish a variety of domestic fowls more
? capable than the common of bearing the heat of the
sun This was a hen and chickens with all
their feathers curled upwards They were thus
capable of giving shade to the body without increasing the heat
They are here named "Kisafu" by the native population
who pay a high prizce price for them when they wish to offer
them as a sacrifice and by the Portuguese ^ they are termed "Arripiada"
or shivering There seems ^ to be a tendency inin nature
to afford varieties bradapted to the convenience of man

There is a kind of very short legged fowls among
? the Boers obtained in consequence of observing that short
such limbed fr ones were more easily caught for transport
in their frequent removals in search of pasture
A similar instance of securing a variety, occurred
with the short legged ^ limbed sheep in America

Returning by way of ^ ascending the Lucalla
into Cazengo we had an opportunity of visiting
several flourishing coffee plantations and
observed that men several men who had begun
with no capital but honest industry had
in the course of a few years acquired a comfortable ^ subsistence
competency One of these Mr Pinto ^ Pinto fairly generously
furnished me with a
a good supply of his excellent
coffee and my men
with a breed of rabbits
to carry to their own
country Their coffee lands granted
by GovtGovernment yielded without much labour
coffee sufficient for all the necessaries of life

The fact of other avenues of wealth opening
? up so readily, seems like an providential invitatinvitation
to forsake the slave trade and engage in lawful
commerce. We saw the female population
employed ^ occupied as usual in the spinning of cotton and
cultivation of their lands ^ Their only instrument
for culture is a
double handled hoe
which is held in both
hands & worked with
a sort of dragging
motion and manyMany of the men
were employed in weaving The latter appear
to be less industrious than the former for they require
a month to finish a single web. There is
83
however not much inducement to industry
for notwithstanding the time consumed in its manu-
facture each web only bring is sold for only 2 shillings

On returniging to Golungo
Alto I found several of my
men laid up ofwith fever -
One of the reasons for my
leaving them there was
that they might recover
from the fatigue of the journey
from LoandaLuanda which may
had much more effect
upon their feet than
hundreds of miles had
in our way Westwards
They had always been
accustomed to moisture in
their own
well watered
land ^ and we certainly had
a super abundance of
that in LondaLoandaLuanda - The
roads fhowever from
LoandaLuanda to Golungo Alto
were both hard and dry
and they suffered severely
in consequence - Two of
them had ^ now fever in the
continued form and
became Jaundiced - The
conjunctiva of their eyes
becoming as yellow
as saffron, and a third
suffered from an attack
of mania - He camesaid to
84
to his companions ^ one day and said
"Remain well! I am called
away by the gods" and
set off at the top of his
speed - The young men
caught him before he had
gone a mile and bound
him - I haBy gentle treatment
and watching for a few
days he recovered - I have
observed several instances
of this kind butin the
country but very few
cases of idiocy - and
I believe that continued
insanity is rare -

While waiting for the
recovery of my men I
visited in company with
my friend Mr Canto the
deserted convent of
St Hilarion at Bango a
few miles North W ofest of
Golungo Alto - It is
situated in a magnificent
valley containing a
population of about numbering
4000 hearths - This is the
abode of the Sova or chief
Bango who still holds
a place of authority
under the Portuguese
The garden of the convent
the church and dormitories
of the bretherenbrethren are still
85
kept in a good state of repair
I looked at the furniture -
couches - and large chests
for holding ^ the provisions of
the brotherhood ^ with interest and would
fain have learned something
of the former occupants
but all the books and
sacred vessels havde
lately been removed to
LoandaLuanda and the graves
of the good men even
stand without any
record Their resting
places
are however
carefully
tended - All speak well
of the Jesuits for having
attended diligently to the
instructions of their children
They were supposed to have
a tendency been willing to take the
part of the people against
the government and
were supplanted by priests
concerning ^ concerning whom no
regret is expressed that
they have been ^ were allowed
to die out - In viewing
the present fruits of
former missions it is
impossible not to feel
that if the Jesuit teaching
has been so permanent
that of protestantsProtestants who
leave the Bible in the
hands of their converts will
not be less abiding
86
The chief Bango has built a
large ^ two storey house close by the
convent but superstitious
feelings fears prevent him
from sleeping in it - The
Portuguese take advantage
of all the gradations in to
which native society has
divided itself - This man for
instance tois still a sova or
chief and has his counsellors
asand maintains the same
state as when the country
was independent - When
any of his people is guilty
of thiefttheft he pays down
the amount of goods
stolen at once, and reimburses
himself out of the property
of the thief so effectually
as to be benefittedbenefited by the
transaction The people under

him are divided into a number of classes
These are his councillors as the highest who
are generally head men of several villages
and the lowest free men the carriers.
One class above them obtains the privilege by
pay of wearing its shows^oes for the chief by paying
for it Another, is the soldiers or militia
pay for the privilege of serving the advantage
being that they are not afterwards liable to be
made carriers. They are also divided
into gentlemen and little gentlemen and though
quite black speak of themselves as white men
87
and of the others who may not wear bootsshoes as "blacks"
men. The men of all these classes
trust to their wives for food and spend most of their
time in drinking the palm toddy This toddy
is the juice of the palm oil tree let out by means
of a puncture which when tapped yields a sweet
clean liquid not at all intoxicating while fresh
but when allowed to stand till the afternoon
causes inebriation and many crimes. This
toddy called malova is the bane of the country Culprits are
continually
brought before
the command-
ants for
crimesassaults com-
mitted through
its influence
Men are
brought with
deep gashes
on their
heads and
one who
had burned
his father's
house I saw
making a
profound
bow into
Mr Canto &
volunteer
to explain
why he
did the deed.

There is also a classsort of free masonsfreemasons' fraternity
named Empacasseiros whose into which no one
is admitted unless he is an expert hunter and
can shoot well with a gun. They are
distinguished by a ^ filletthong of ^ buffalo hide around their
heads and are employed as messengers in all
cases requiring express. and are very trustworthy
and when on active service form the best native
troops the Portuguese possess. The militia
are of no value as soldiers but cost the
country nothing being supported by their wives
Their duties are chiefly to guard the residences
of Commandants and act as police The
chief recreations of these natives of Angola people are marriages
and funerals When a young woman is about
to be married she is placed in a hut alone
and anointed with various unguents and many
incantations are employed in order to secure
good fortune and fruitfulness After some
days she is taken to another hut and ^ ornamentedadorned
with all the richest clothing and ornaments
that the relatives can either lend or borrow
She is then placed in a public situation
and she is saluted ^ as a lady and receives presents are made

Here as almost everywhere in
the South the height of good fortune
is to bear sons - They often leave
a husband altogether if they
have daughters only - In their
dances ^ when any one may ^ wish to deride
another in the accompanying
song a line is introduced
"so & so has no children and never
will get any" - She feels the insult
so keenly, asit is not
uncommon for her to
rush away and commit
suicide

div.p:
88
by all her acquaintencesacquaintances who engage in dance
feasts & drinks for several days are placed
around her. After this she is taken to the residence
of her husband where she has a hut for herself and
becomes one of several wives for polygamy is general
Dancing feasting and drinking on such occasions are
prolonged for several days. In cases of
separation the woman returns to her father's family
and the husband receives back what he gave for
her. In nearly all
cases a
man gives
a price for
the wife
and in
cases of
mulattoes
as much
as £60. is
often given
to the
mulparents
of the
bride - This
is one of
the evils
the bishop
was trying
to remedy (Par.Paragraph)? In cases of death the body is kept
several days and there is a grand concourse of
both sexes with beating of drums and dances
and debauchery wh kept up with feasting &c
according to the means of the relatives.
It is The great ambition of many of the blacks
of Angola is to give their friends an expensive funeral
Often when one is asked to sell a pig he replies
"I am keeping it in case of the death of any of my
friends" aA pig is
usually slaughtered
& eaten
on the last
day of the
ceremonies and its head thrown into the nearest
steam or river A native will sometimes appear
intoxicated on these occasions and if blamed
for his intemperance will reply "Why! My Mother
is dead" as if he thought it a perfect justification

The expenses of funeral are so heavy that often
years elapse before they can defray them

These people are said to be very litigious and
obstinate as Constant disputes are taking place
respecting their lands A case came before
the weekly court of the commandant involving
property in a palm tree worth two pence
The judge advised the pursuer to withdraw the case
as the ^ mere expenses of entering it would be much more
than the cost of the tree "O No" said he "I have
a piece of calico with me for the clerk and money
for yourself ItsIt's my right I will not forgoforego it"
89
The calico itself cost 3 or 4 shillings. They
rejoice if they can say of an enemy "I took him
before the court"

My friend Mr Canto the Commandant being
seized with fever in a severe form it afforded
me much pleasure to attend him in his sickness
who had been ˄ so kind to me in mine. heHe Hwas for
some time in a state of insensibility and I having
the charge of his establishment had thus an
opportunity of observing the workings of slavery

When a Master is ill the slaves run riot
among the eatables I did not know this until I
observed that every time the sugar basin came to
the table it was empty. On visiting my
patient by night I passed along a corridor
and unexpectedly came upon the washerwoman
eating pine applespineapples and sugar. I All the
sweetmeats were devoured and it was difficult
for me to get even bread & butter until I took
the precaution to lock the pantry door
Probably the slaves thought as both they and the
luxuries belonged to the Master were the Master's
property there was no ^ good reason
why they should be kept apart

Debarred by my precaution from these sources
of enjoyment they took to killing the fowls & goats
and when the animals was quite dead brought them
to me saying "We found this lying out there" They
then enjoyed a feast of flesh. A feeling of
insecurity prevails throughout this country. itIt is quite
common to furnish visitors with the keys to their
rooms When called on to come to breakfast
or dinner each locks his door puts the key
in his pocket At Kolobeng we never
90
locked our doors by night or day for months together
but there slavery is unknown. The Portuguese do
not seem at all bgigoted in their attachment to
slavery nor yet in their prejudices against colour
Mr Canto gave ^ mean entertainments in order to
draw all classes together and promote a general
good will. Two Sovas or native chiefs were present
and took their places without the least appearance
of embarassmentembarrassment - The sova of Kilombo appeared
in the dress of a General and the sova of Bango was
gaily attired in a red coat profusely ornamented
with tinsel. The latter had a band of musicians
with him consisting of six trumpeters and four
drummers who performed very well These men are fond
of titles & the Portuguese
GovtGovernment humours them
by conferring honorary
captaincyies & The sova of
Bango was at present
anxious to obtain the
title of "Major of all the
Sovas"
At the table of other gentlemen I observed ^ the same thing
constantly occurring
persons of colour taking their seats and they were
addressed on terms of equality At this
meeting Mr Canto communicated some ideas
which I had comwritten out on the dignity of labour
and the superiority of free over slave labour

The Portuguese gentlemen present were anxiously
expecting an arrival of fresh American cotton seed
from Mr Gabriel They are now in the
transition state from unlawful to lawful
trade and turn eagerly to cotton coffee &
sugar as new sources of wealth. Mr Canto
had been commissioned by them to purchase 3
sugar mills. As ourOur cruizerscruisers have been the
principal agents in compelling them to abandon
the slave trade & our GovtGovernment in furnishing them with
a supply of cotton seed showed a wisegenerous intention
to aid them in commencing a more stable
enterprize honourable course. It can
scarcely be believed however that after
91
Lord Clarendon had been at the trouble of procuring
fresh cotton seed through our minister at
Washington and had sent it out to the care
of H. M.Her Majesty's Commissioner at LoandaLuanda, from probably
having fallen into the hands of a few incorrigible
slave traders it never reached its destination
It was probably cast into the sea off Ambriz
and my friends at Golungo Alto were left without
the means of commencing a new enterprise

In speaking to Mr Canto mentioned
that there is now much more cotton in the country
than can be consumed and if he had possession of
a few hundred pounds he would buy up all the
oil and cotton at a fair price and thereby
produce quite a revolution in the agriculture of
the country These commodities are not
produced in greater quantity because the
people have no market for those which now
spring up almost spontaneously around
them The above was put
down in my journal
when I had no idea
that enlarged
supplies of
cotton
from new
sources fresh supplies
of cotton were so
much needed at
home. It is common to cut down cotton
trees as a nuisance and cultivate beans, potatoes
and manioc sufficient only for their own
consumption The rents paid for gardens
belonging to the old convents are merely nominal
varying from one shilling to three pounds per annum
The higher rents being realized from those in immediate
vicinity of LoandaLuanda none but the Portuguese or native
can rent them ?

92
discovered the Tsetse that no insect might light
upon it The change of diet here may have had
some influence in producing the disease for I was
informed by Dr WalweitschWelwitsch a German naturalist
whom we found pursuing his arduous labours here
that of 658 kinds of grasses found at LoandaLuanda only
3 or 4 very diminutive species exist here and these of the
most diminutive
kinds The
24 ^ different species of grass of Golungo Alto are nearly all
gigantic Indeed gigantic grasses, climbers
shrubs ^ and trees with but few plants constitute the vegetation
of this region

20th NovNovember Before leaving we observed had
anAn eclipse of the Sun which I had had anxiously hoped
to observe with a view of delivering the longitude
happened this morning and as often took place
in this cloudy climate the sun was covered 4
minutes before it began. It then shone forth
When it shone forth the eclipse was in progress
and a few minutes before it should have ended
according to my calculation The sun was
Par-Paragraph again completely obscured ^ The greatest ^ patience &
perseverance
are required
if one
wishes
to ascertain
his position
when it is
the rainy
season
ʃ Before leaving I had an opportunity of observing
a curious insect which inhabits the trees of the fig
family (Ficus)
& upwards
of twenty
species such are found here Seven or eight of them cluster round a spot
on one of the smaller branches and there keep up
a constant distillation of a clear fluid which
dropping to the ground forms a little puddle below
If a vessel is placed under them in the evening
it contains 3 or 4 pintsa large quantity of fluid in the
morning The natives say that if a drop
falls into the eyes it causes inflamationinflammation
of these organs To the question whence
is this fluid derived the people sayreply that
the insects suck it out of the tree, but it
93
is scarcely possible that the tree can yield so
much A similar insect but much smaller
insect may be observed ^ seen in Scotland named
Do you know
its name?
If so put
it in - We
call it
Spittley Jock! which forms a mass of fou of froth on the a
stalk of grass but it seems equally unlikely
that so much moisture can flow in the pores
of graminaceous plants. In the case of
plants ^ branches of the fig ^ tree the point the insects congregate
on is soon marked by a number of incipient
roots such as thrown out when a brcutting is
inserted in the ground for the purpose of starting
another tree. I am inclined to believe that the
is both the Scotch and African insects belong
to the same family and differ only in the latter
being 5 or 6 times larger than the former, and
that the chief part of the moisture is derived
from the atmosphere I leave it for naturalists
to decide whether these little creatures have
the power of distilling both by night and day as
much water as they please and are more
independent than Her MHer Majesty's Steamships which
with their have an aparatusapparatus for condensing steam, for
without coal their abundant supplies of sea-
water are of no avail. I tried the following
experiment finding a number ^ colony of these insects
busily distilling on thea branch of the Riscinisus ^
Communis or common castor oil plant I
denuded about twenty inches of the bark on
the tree side of the insects and scraped away
all the inner bark so as to destroy all the
ascending vessels I also cut a hole in the
side of the branch and reaching to the pith
middle then cut out the pith and internal
vessels. The distillation was then going on
94
at the rate of one drop each 67 seconds. Next
morning the distillation so far from being affected by
the attempt to stop the supplies supposing they had
come up through the branch from the tree was increased
to a drop every 5 seconds or 12 drops per minute which
at the sur I then cut the branch so much
that during the day it broke but they still went
on at the rate of a drop every 5 seconds which
Can you
calculate
how many
pints in
24 hours
How many
drops in
a pint
if so state
the amount
I have forgot
my chemistry another colony on a branch of the same tree gave
a drop every 17 seconds only I finally cut off
the branch altogether but this was too much for
their patience for they immediately decamped
as insects will do from either a dead branch
or dead animal as Indian hunters willsoon know
should they sit down on a recently killed bear.

The presence of greater moisture in the
air increased the power of these distillers
the period of greatest activity was in the
morning when the air wasand everything else was
charged with dew

Having but one day left
for experiment, I found again that another
colony on a denuded branch ^ denuded in the same way yielded a drop
every 2 seconds andwhile a colony on a branch
untouched yielded a drop every 11 seconds
I regretted somewhat the want of time to institute
another experiment namely to cut a branch
and place it in water so as to keep up it in life
and then observe if there was any diminution of
the quality of water This alone seewas wanting
to make it certain that they draw water from
the atmosphere I imagine that they have some
passage which we are not aware besides that
nervous influence which causes constant motion
95
to our own involuntary muscles, the power of
life long action without fatigue The reader
will remember in connection ^ with this
insect the
case already
mentioned
DecDecember 14 27 NovNovember My men Both myself and men having
recovered from severe attacks of fever we left the
hospitable residence of Mr Canto with a deep sense
of his kindness to us all, and proceeded on our way to
Ambaca Frequent rains had fallen in October
and November which was nearly always accompanied
with thunder. Occasionally the quantity of moisture
in the atmosphere is greatly increased without any
visible cause this imparts a gr sensation of
considerable cold though the thermometer shows
exhibits indicates no fall of the mercury The greater
humidity in the air affording a better conducting
medium for the heat of the radiation of heat
from the body is as dangerous as a sudden fall
of the thermometer it causes considerable disease
among the natives and this season is denominated
"CarneiradaCarneirado" as if ^ by the disease they were slaughtered like sheep a great number of sheep were
slaughtered The season ^ of these changes which is most favourable
for Europeans is the most unhealthy for the native
population, and this is by no means a climate in
which either natives or Europeans can indulge in
"irregularities" without impunity

We were Owing to the weakness of the men who had
been sick we were able to march but small
short ^ distances Three and a half hours brought us to
the banks of the Caloi a small stream which flows
into the Senza This is one of the parts of the
country reputed to contain yield Petroleum
but the geological formation being mica schist
dipping towards the eastward did not promise
much for our finding it. Our hospitable friend ^ Mr Mellot
96
accompanied us to another little river thcalled the
Quango where I saw two fine boys the sons of the sub-
Commandant ^ Mr Feltao who though only from 6 to 8 years
old were subject to fever. Our We then passed
on in the bright sunlight the whole country looking so
fresh and green after the rains and everything so cheering
one could not but wonder to find the country so
feverish We found at on reaching Ambaca
that the gallant old soldier Laurence Jose Marquis
had since our passing Icoloilo i BengoIcolo e Bengo been
promoted on account of his ^ stern integrity to the GovtGovernment
of this important district These command-
The office of Commandant^ant -ancies areis much coveted by the officers ^ of the line who come to
Angola not so much for the actual amount of
salary but ^ as for the perquisites which ^ when managed skilfully in the course of
a few years makes one rich. An idea may be
formed of the conduct of some of these officials from
the following extract from the Bal Boletim of
LoandaLuanda of 28th OctOctober 1854 "The acting GovrGovernor-General
of the province of Angola and its dependencies
determines as follows. Having instituted an
investigation (Syndecancia) against the
? Commandant of the fort of Massangano a captcaptain
of the army of Portugal in commission in this province
Z. M. C. B. on account of numerous complaints which
have come before this GovtGovernment of violences and extortions
practised by the said commandant and those
complaints appearing by the result of the investigation
to be well founded it will be convenient to
exonerate the capt.captain referred to from the
command of the fort of to which he
had been nominated by the Portfolio of this
general GovtGovernment NoNumber 41 of 27 DecDecember of the past year
and if not otherwise determined the same official
97
shall be judged by a Council of War for the criminal
acts which are to him attributed" The Council
of War by which these gentlemen delinquents always
prefer to be judged is composed of men who eagerly
expect to occupy the office of Commandant themselves and
anticipate ^ their own trial for similar acts ^ at some future time The severest
sentence a Council of War passes awards is a few
weeks suspension from his
office in
his RegiementRegiment Even this public mention
of their crimes attaches no stigma to the ^ a man's character

This want of official integrity would from which
is not at all attributable to the Home GovtGovernment of Portugal
would prove a serious impediment in the way of
foreign enterprizeenterprise developing the resources of this
rich province, and to this same cause indeed
may be ascribed the failure of the Portuguese laws
for the entire suppression of the slave trade. The officers
ought to
recievereceive
higher pay
if integrity
is expected
from them -
At present
a captainscaptain's
pay for
a year
will only
keep him
in good
uniform
The high pay
our own
officers recievereceive
has manifest
advantages
Before On leaving Ambaca we received a present
of ten head of cattle from ^ Mr Schutt a merchant in of
LoandaLuanda and as it shows the cheapness of
provisions here I may mention that the cost was
only about a guinea per head. On crossing the
Lucalla we made a detour to the South in order
to visit the famous rocks of Pungo Andongo
asAs soon as we crossed the rivulet Lotete a change
in the vegetation of the country is apparent
We find trees identical with those to be seen south
of the Chobe The grass too stands in tufts and is
of that kind which the natives consider to be best adapted
for cattle Two species of ^ grape bearing vines abound
every where in this district and The influence
of their good pasturage is seen in the plump condition
of the cattle. In ^ all my previous inquiries respecting
the ^ vegetable products of Angola I was invariably directed
98
to Pungo Andongo. Do you grow wheat? “O yes
in Pungo Andongo" Grapes, Figs or Peaches? "O yes
in Pungo Andongo" Do you make butter, cheese &c
The uniform answer was “O yes there is abundance
of all these ˄ in Pungo Andongo" But when we arrived inhere
we found that the answers all referred to the activity
of one man ^ Colonel Manuel Antonio Pires The
presence of the wild grape shows that the
? tame might be cultivated with success The
wheat grows wild well without irrigation
and any one who tasted the butter & cheese at the
table of Mr ColnelColonel Pires would prefer them
to the ^ stale produce of the Irish dairy in general use
throughout that country The cattle in
this country are seldom milked on account of
the strong prejudice which the Portuguese entertain
against the use of milk They beleivebelieve that it
may be used with safety in the mornings
but if taken after midday willthat it will cause
pre fever. It seemed to me there was not
much reason for carefully avoiding a few drops
in their coffee after dinner after having devoured
ten times the amount in the shape of cheese at
dinner The fort of Pungo Andongo
is situated in the midst of a group of curious
columnar shaped rocks each of which is upwards
of three hundred feet in height They are composed
of conglomerate made up of a great variety of
rounded pieces in a matrix of dark red sand-
stone They rest on a thick stratum of
this last rock with very few of the pebbles
in its substance On this a fossil palm
has been found and if of the same age with those
on the eastern side of the country continent
99
on which similar palms now lie there may
be coal underneath this as well as under that at
Tete The asserted existence of Petroleum
springs at Dande and near Cambambe would
seem to indicate the presence of this useful mineral
though I am not aware of anyone having actually seen
a seam of coal tilted up to a surface in Angola

In the country near to this station
was a large number of ^ the ancient burial places
of the Jinga They^se are simply large mounds of stones
with pieces of pottery drinking and cooking vessels
of rude pottery Some are arranged in a
circular form two or three yards in diameter
shaped like a haycock There is not a single
vestige of any inscription. The natives of
Angola generally have a strange predilection
for burying their dead on the sides of the most
frequent paths They have a particular
anxiety to secure the point when cross roads
meet The graves ARround and on the graves
are planted tree Euphorbias and other species of
that family On the grave itself they place
also water bottles ^ broken pipes broken cookery vessels &
sometimes a little bow and arrow

The Portuguese GovtGovernment wishing to prevent this
custom have affixed a penalty to any one
burying in the roads and appointed places of
public sepulture in every district in this
country The people persist however in
spite of the most stringent enforcement of the
law The country between
